title: 820-00165 orange light, no power
message:
No fan spin, orange light regardless of battery presence on early 2015 Macbook Air. No water damage or visible corrosion. Tested with other power board.

Getting 3.47 V (instead of 3.42 V) on PP3V42_G3H, 15.1 (possibly instead of 18.5 V or at least instead of 14.85 V) on PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL using 45 W charger. I'm a bit new to this - are these values normal for these lines?

Since it seems like the onewire circuit is likely fine and just a multimeter precision thing, perhaps the issue lies with the battery circuit? I can't find much info about the specific conditions that make the orange light show up. Which general circuit should I be looking at?

title: 820-00165 orange light, no power
message: Sorry, did I do something wrong when posting?

title: 820-00165 orange light, no power
message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

Good to have orange light on Magsafe; is sign that SMC works, at least partially.

No water spill, but no other history available?

Do you get 3V3_S5/SUS?

title: 820-00165 orange light, no power
message:
Hello! Sorry for the misunderstanding. No water spill, just a few bits of dirt and hair. Customer report:
Plugged laptop in and left it for a few hours, came back and it had turned off completely. Pressed power button and machine didn't turn on. Charger light remained orange even after hours of charging.

Just made a mistake - the multimeter touched R5501 pin 1 (PPBUS_G3H) when testing PPDCIN_G3H_ISOL on R7005 pin 1. There was a spark and R7005 seems to have damage on its solder pad on board. Still has an orange light, though. Is it likely that I can just replace that resistor?

title: 820-00165 orange light, no power
message: (I should clarify that the top of the resistor seems fine - the black circle of 'damage' is actually on the thin solder layer on top of the pad.)

title: 820-00165 orange light, no power
message:
Do you get orange light with charger only (no battery)?
If yes, R7005 is good; if not, change it.

I'm still waiting you to reply my questions...

title: 820-00165 orange light, no power
message:
PP3V3_S5: 0.5876 V
PP3V3_SUS: 0.0 V

Still get orange light with charger. Does that mean the short, which caused the spark and noise, didn't break anything?

title: 820-00165 orange light, no power
message: P3V3SUS_EN is 0, PM_SLP_SUS_L is 0, and that comes out of the CPU which seems concerning. PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK is 0, ALL_SYS_PWRGD is 0, PP3V3_S0 is missing. Sorry that might be too much info - followed it from P3V3SUS_EN as you can tell but got a little stuck at PP3V3_S0.

title: 820-00165 orange light, no power
message:
I don't understand your concern about orange light; you already got a reply.
"Good to have orange light on Magsafe"

As missing 3V3_S5, let us know if you have correct PPBUS_G3H voltage.

title: 820-00165 orange light, no power
message: PPBUS_G3H is 0 V, but I think it was the correct 8.6 V before I seemingly bridged R7005 and R5501.

title: 820-00165 orange light, no power
message:
Post some voltages for U7100; pins 1, 2, 3, 9, 12, 13, 15, 17, 19, 20, 27.
Also post diode mode to ground at L7130.

And get fine lead probes for multimeter...
[URL unfurl="true"]https://www.aliexpress.com/item/32817572283.html?spm=a2g0o.productlist.0.0.47274ee57ZJ4ZJ&algo_pvid=3aab1b83-dc97-4682-b216-c6261954f410&algo_expid=3aab1b83-dc97-4682-b216-c6261954f410-1&btsid=0b0a0ae215951573932273888ed4d0&ws_ab_test=searchweb0_0,searchweb201602_,searchweb201603_[/URL]

title: 820-00165 orange light, no power
message:
L7130: ~1.0 kΩ
CHGR_AGATE (pin 1): 3.3 mV (0 V)
CHGR_DCIN (pin 2): 14.6 V
CHGR_ACIN (pin 3): 3.96 V (measured in DC but the name suggests AC?) 0 V measured in AC
CHGR_AMON (pin 9): 29.5 mV
PP3V42_G3H (pin 12): 3.468 V
CHGR_RST_L (pin 13): 3.3 V
CHGR_BMON (pin 15): 55 mV
CHGR_CSO_N (pin 17): 8.6 V
PP5V1_CHGR_VDD (pin 19): 5.05 V
PP5V1_CHGR_VDDP (pin 20): 5.0 V
CHGR_CSI_N (pin 27): 14.55 V

title: 820-00165 orange light, no power
message: Sorry, the L7130 measurement is wrong. I can't give you one answer - it changes over time. There is a pattern: starts at ~6 MΩ, goes down over ~10 seconds to 5 kΩ, then back up again by about 3 kΩ / second.

title: 820-00165 orange light, no power
message: I used the line names because I got the values from probe points and other componenets - the multimeter's tips would bridge the pins on U7100.

title: 820-00165 orange light, no power
message:
" PPBUS_G3H is 0 V 
------------------
CHGR_CSO_N (pin 17): 8.6 V"
Are you sure?
Then F7140 is open; check diode mode at pin 2.

"L7130: ~1.0 kΩ"
I said diode mode, not ohm scale...

title: 820-00165 orange light, no power
message: Oh sorry. Diode mode on L7130: 0.15 V. And yes I'm very sure about pin 17. Black on F7140 pin 2 and red on ground with diode mode: 0 V.

title: 820-00165 orange light, no power
message:
So F7140 is burnt and you also have a short on PPBUS_G3H.
Now post exact ohm value of this short.
And compare with all big coils to ground...

title: 820-00165 orange light, no power
message: Yep, just checked on resistance mode with F7140 and it's in the MΩs so that's definitely going to have to be replaced. Although actually when I reverse the black and red it's just 1 kΩ. Before I go forward: you mean place red probe on, say, F7140 pin 2 and black on ground in resistance mode with no power? Doing that I get 0.3, 0.2 Ω.

title: 820-00165 orange light, no power
message:
Using that strategy:
L2920 pin 1: 947 Ω
L7310, L7320 pin 1: both 17.2 Ω
L7560 pin 1: 5.25 kΩ
L7520 pin 1: infinite
I suspect I misinterpreted your request.

title: 820-00165 orange light, no power
message:
You forgot L7430 and L7630...

"you mean place red probe on, say, F7140 pin 2 and black on ground"
Not important when measure ohm scale.
But is VERY IMPORTANT to put red probe to ground on diode mode.
Good to do it on ohm scale too, and never get confused.

title: 820-00165 orange light, no power
message:
L7430: 649 Ω
L7630: 229.9 Ω
Both with red on pin 1 and black on ground.

title: 820-00165 orange light, no power
message:
Looks like your lucky day; should be just a shorted cap.

If you are sure about coils measurments, then is safe to inject voltage on PPBUS_G3H.
Start with 1V, as you have a pure short practically (0.3 ohm).
You will need powerfull lab power supply; more than 10A required at 1V maybe.

title: 820-00165 orange light, no power
message:
Well darn; I don't have a lab power supply. Although as for the coils, can you make sure I'm sure, so to speak:
- Put red on pin 1 of each, black on ground
- On some of the coils, it took about 10 seconds or so for the reading to stabilize
Is there any other way to find it?

title: 820-00165 orange light, no power
message:
Connect always red probe to ground, no matter diode mode, or ohm scale.
Coil values are far away of short in your case.

title: 820-00165 orange light, no power
message: So red probe to ground for resistance mode, continuity mode, and diode mode, and black to ground for voltage modes? And is there a way I can find the capacitor without a power supply?

title: 820-00165 orange light, no power
message:
Sometime can be found, if has some burnt dot on it.
Get mentioned PSU, if you want to repair boards...

title: 820-00165 orange light, no power
message: Sorry to raise the post back up the list, but do you have the names of any good ones that I can get (more than 10 A)?

message:
